column1: The first detected cases of the COVID-19 pandemic in Malaysia were found in January 2020
column2: from foreign nationals entering the country. In February the first local Malaysian case was identified. A Tablighi Jamaat event held at the Masjid Jamek Sri Petaling in Kuala Lumpur
column4: was linked to a significant spike in cases both in Malaysia and abroad. At one point
column5: almost two-thirds of cases in the country were linked to this event. A "Movement Control Order" was announced on 16 March
column6: and the next day the first deaths in the country were reported.

column1: The number of active cases peaked in April and slowly declined
column2: leading to a relaxation of lockdown restrictions over the next several months. In mid-September
column3: an outbreak of cases in Sabah and Kedah led to a resurgence of COVID-19 cases throughout the country.

column1: Eight Chinese nationals were quarantined at a hotel in Johor Bahru on 24 January after coming into contact with an infected person in neighbouring Singapore. Despite early reports of them testing negative for the virus
column2: three of them were confirmed to be infected on 25 January and subsequently quarantined at the Sungai Buloh Hospital in Selangor. The Malaysian health ministry published guidelines on the virus and established designated hospitals in each of Malaysia's states to manage any positive cases. The Malaysian public were reminded by local authorities to take precautionary measures in the wake of the virus threat with those travelling to China have been advised to stay away from animal farms and markets in the country and to not eat raw or semi-cooked meats. Following several earlier suspected cases in Sabah's capital of Kota Kinabalu
column3: all direct flights between the state with China were stopped indefinitely.On 24 January
column4: a two-year-old child who was suspected to have been infected was detained along with their parents. The parents refused quarantine and were detained the next day by police at Senai International Airport before returning to China. The patient including others who refused quarantine were subsequently placed under close monitoring by the local Health Ministry. On 26 January
column5: a fourth case of the virus
column7: was detected. A suspected case was also detected in the state of Kedah's island of Langkawi involving two female Chinese nationals with both victims quarantined at the Sultanah Maliha Hospital; one later confirmed positive on 29 January. With the increasing number of cases reported in neighbouring Thailand
column8: both the state of Kedah and Penang tightened their borders by conducting stringent checks at its international entry points. A Chinese female national in Bintulu of Sarawak also suspected of having contracted the virus led to the state tightening its border and postponing direct flights to Hainan
column9: despite a recently signed memorandum of understanding (MoU) establishing direct flights with Sarawak.Of the total of 25 Chinese nationals in Sabah earlier suspected of having contracted the virus

column1: In response to a spike in cases resulting from the Kuala Lumpur Tabligh Jamaat cluster originating at "Masjid Jamek Sri Petaling
column2:
the Ministry of Health announced that Malaysia was in late containment stage and that a special meeting would be held to discuss the next course of action.

On 16 March, Prime Minister Muhyiddin Yassin announced that the federal government would be imposing a nationwide lockdown known as the Movement Control Order (MCO), which would come into effect on 18 March and last for two weeks.On 17 March, Malaysia reported its first two deaths from the coronavirus, a 60-year-old priest from Emmanuel Baptist Church in Kuching, Sarawak and a 34-year-old participant of the Muslim religious gathering in Sri Petaling from Johor Bahru, Johor.On 19 March, Health Director-General Noor Hisham once again urged people to stay home, saying that Malaysia has a small chance of blocking the rapid spread of coronavirus disease as compared to the current situation facing by Italy; stating that if it misses the third wave of infection, the situation will be out of control similar to what happened in Italy. He also indicated that the Government would extend the movement restriction order" for another 14 days. The Prime Minister also appealed to all Malaysians to adhere to the movement control in order to prevent further infections within the country.On 20 March
column3: it was reported that 15 medical personnel had contracted COVID-19
column4: with one being placed in an intensive care unit (ICU). On 21 March
column5: it was reported that a total of six Malaysian police officers had been infected by the virus while serving their duty.On 25 March
column6: a total of 72 Malaysia's health workers have been infected by the virus. On 26 March
column7: the Malaysian royal household confirmed that seven officers from the nation's National Palace had been confirmed positive
column8: which caused Malaysia's head of state
column9: Abdullah of Pahang and his spouse to be put into quarantine
column10: although they themselves had undergone COVID-19 tests with negative results.

column1: On 3 April Director-General Noor Hisham stated the sudden spike on new cases were not the 'third wave'
column2: but largely due to active case detections on areas affected by Enhanced Movement Controlled Order
column3: a stricter version of the MCO. On 5 April

column5: which involved a person with a travel history to Italy
column6: and now had grew as far as the third generation
column7: with 37 cases and five fatalities as of the day. On 6 April two more clusters had been identified: a church gathering at Kuching which resulted in 83 cases and two fatalities and a wedding at Bandar Baru Bangi which led to 88 cases. Both clusters infected people across five generations. On 8 April
column8: the number of cases breached the 4

column14: and 28 virus clusters were detected nationwide so far.15 April was the first date that Malaysia recorded fewer than 100 new cases since 14 March. On 18 April a new cluster had been identified among healthcare workers in three government hospitals in Sabah with 31 cases. On 19 April new cluster had been identified which consisted of 43 students returning from Temboro
column16: Indonesia. On 22 April a new cluster had been identified in Pengerang with 15 cases. 72 of the cases reported on 29 April came from the Magetan cluster.
